subs.text: @b0rk [link] was allowing this for a long time but then stopped. It's a very rational thing and I didn't understand their reason for stopping. My friend @rswilbourn is a DNS expert, I wonder if he knows why roots of domains can't be cnames, or can they?
subs.rawText:
@b0rk https://t.co/DQBgJU09hv was allowing this for a long time but then stopped. It's a very rational thing and I didn't understand their reason for stopping. 

My friend @rswilbourn is a DNS expert, I wonder if he knows why roots of domains can't be cnames, or can they?

subs.text: The thing that's so scary about what's happening in Ukraine, is the kind of killing and destroying they're doing is getting close to the kind of destruction a nuclear weapon does.
subs.rawText: The thing that's so scary about what's happening in Ukraine, is the kind of killing and destroying they're doing is getting close to the kind of destruction a nuclear weapon does.

subs.text:
People who could do what the Russians do are the kind of people who could fire off the nukes.

Perhaps we have to stop thinking about provoking them and start imagining how provoked we will let ourselves be without doing something to stop it.
subs.rawText:
People who could do what the Russians do are the kind of people who could fire off the nukes.

subs.text:
At some point we will have to call their bluff, right? 

And in the meantime, the Repubs in Congress are daring us to see them for exactly what they are, the enemy within. They are on the same team as the Russians. 

We have to assume their hearts are as cold as Putin's.

Twitter your algorithm is broken.

subs.text: I assumed there was a way to turn the algorithm off, but it doesn't appear there is. So it's not the algorithm that's broken it's the whole product. Wasn't the idea of Twitter that you could quickly see some new stuff? It's always the same for me. [link]

subs.text:
@TaylorLorenz He might be really good for Twitter's board.

He's actually made software, himself -- and presumably knows how to write a bug report.

And he uses the product. I don't imagine too many of the other board members at Twitter really use it.

Leadership from users, what a concept. üòÄ

subs.text: 1/3 If you're a #toolsforthought person, you must've seen me beating the drum for interop between outliners. My preferred format is OPML, but if real interop is built with another format, I'll support it in Drummer.
subs.rawText: 1/3 If you're a #toolsforthought person, you must've seen me beating the drum for interop between outliners. My preferred format is OPML, but if real interop is built with another format, I'll support it in Drummer.

subs.text: 2/3 I eased up on my evangelism for OPML because the various teams in #tft seem busy focused on their own products, and aren't thinking a lot about interop these days, I guess. So I got to work on another project, but I'll be coming back to this. I do not give up easily. :-)
subs.rawText: 2/3 I eased up on my evangelism for OPML because the various teams in #tft seem busy focused on their own products, and aren't thinking a lot about interop these days, I guess. So I got to work on another project, but I'll be coming back to this. I do not give up easily. :-)

subs.text: 3/3 In the meantime, all of my public outlines can be read in any tool that supports OPML. For example this outline of a talk I gave to a class at CUNY yesterday. A link in the next message in this thread.
subs.rawText: 3/3 In the meantime, all of my public outlines can be read in any tool that supports OPML. For example this outline of a talk I gave to a class at CUNY yesterday. A link in the next message in this thread.

subs.text: If Twitter and Facebook had been federated from the start, like the web or email, or the internet itself, the companies wouldn't be in any way responsible for what's posted on the network. They would just be one node and would be unable to cut anyone off.

subs.text: 1/4 BTW, people who think the web is "over" don't understand imho how technology flows. The web is basically repurposed Unix. It arrived the decade after the "PC revolution." Conventional wisdom said that Unix was a small niche OS that programmers liked, but users primarily used

subs.text:
Another related thought.

Did you know Twitter is a feed reader?

It is except it's private, doesn't use RSS.

You could build a feed reader, based on RSS that had Twitter's user experience. It can be done. 

But why haven't RSS-based feed readers evolved to work like Twitter?
subs.rawText:

subs.text: I sat down at the breakfast table to solve the Wordle puzzle for the day. I sad to solve it in less than a minute. Now what to do? Guess I have to get to work! ;-)
subs.rawText: I sat down at the breakfast table to solve the Wordle puzzle for the day. I sad to solve it in less than a minute. Now what to do? Guess I have to get to work! ;-)

subs.text: BTW -- I find that only my subconscious mind can solve the puzzle, to actually see the solution. I can analytically arrange for the clues to be available to my subconsciousl but the word pops into my mind in an instant. I have no awareness of what the process is.
subs.rawText: BTW -- I find that only my subconscious mind can solve the puzzle, to actually see the solution. I can analytically arrange for the clues to be available to my subconsciousl but the word pops into my mind in an instant. I have no awareness of what the process is.

subs.text: Usually I'm sure when I have the answer. Today I wasn't even sure the correct word was actually a word! What a nice surprise when all five letters came out green and then did their little dance. üòç
subs.rawText: Usually I'm sure when I have the answer. Today I wasn't even sure the correct word was actually a word! What a nice surprise when all five letters came out green and then did their little dance. üòç

subs.text: @KenSmith heh this is a question i've been asking for years. in the early days of blogging i tried to get an online news group to pop up to cover Linux. it didn't happen. as long as i was pushing it myself it had momentum, when i stepped back, nothing.
subs.rawText: @KenSmith heh this is a question i've been asking for years. in the early days of blogging i tried to get an online news group to pop up to cover Linux. it didn't happen. as long as i was pushing it myself it had momentum, when i stepped back, nothing.

subs.text:
@TaylorLorenz Taylor, I was for a while the center of the blogging world, and all the abuse we were gathering was aimed at me. 

People would figure out who I was dating, and then go after them. Same for the people who worked with me.
subs.rawText:
@TaylorLorenz Taylor, I was for a while the center of the blogging world, and all the abuse we were gathering was aimed at me. 

People would figure out who I was dating, and then go after them. Same for the people who worked with me.

subs.text:
@TaylorLorenz Eventually I deliberately cut down on my fame. To take the focus off me. A lifestyle choice. 

I don't know that there's any other way out of the problem. Writing about it publicly only makes it worse I found. Very little sympathy out there for the person at or near the top.
subs.rawText:
@TaylorLorenz Eventually I deliberately cut down on my fame. To take the focus off me. A lifestyle choice. 

I don't know that there's any other way out of the problem. Writing about it publicly only makes it worse I found. Very little sympathy out there for the person at or near the top.

subs.text: @TaylorLorenz Some of the abuse came from people who worked for the big tech companies who were threatened by the work we were doing, btw. Hard to say if the companies put them up to it, but I'm sure it didn't hurt their careers.
subs.rawText: @TaylorLorenz Some of the abuse came from people who worked for the big tech companies who were threatened by the work we were doing, btw. Hard to say if the companies put them up to it, but I'm sure it didn't hurt their careers.

subs.text: I heard a BBC reporter ask a Ukrainian official if they would attack Russian military in Russia. What kind of question is that. Of course they would. It's a war. Russia attacked Ukraine. All of Russia is a fair target for the Ukraine military.
